docs.lead_paragraph: BETSY cuddled next to Charlie on the bed, and both ignored the nonstop television. She kissed his neck, ever so gently, and a nice moment started getting nicer. Suddenly, the door flew open and three nurses, two doctors and who knows who else burst into Room 319. Electronic monitors down the hall had indicated an alarming change in Charlie's heartbeat, so a medical team raced to the rescue. Betsy, who married Charles Schultz three years ago, turned bright red. ''Never again,'' she said as she finished telling the story. ''Tempting, but that's it.''

headline.main: Life on Life Row; In the Wrenching Wait for New Hearts, the 'Pole People' at Mt. Sinai Wind Up Forging a Family

docs.abstract: Patients at Guggenheim Pavilion of Mount Sinai Medical Center in New York, where people with failing hearts wait for transplants, have created small community defined by immense empathy and small kindnesses; photos (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: IN the battle for insurance claims, Vivian Gallo describes herself as an advocate for hire. ''Most people don't understand the complexities of their insurance claim coverages, or do they know how to effectively communicate with insurance companies,'' said Ms. Gallo, a former insurance industry executive with more than 20 years' experience in accident and health insurance.

headline.main: Trained Eye for Decoding Insurance Claims

docs.abstract: Vivian Gallo, former insurance industry executive with more than 20 years' experience in accident and health insurance, says most people do not understand complexities of their health insurance claim coverages, nor do they know how to effectively communicate with insurance companies; Gallo now serves as an insurance claims troubleshooter to help clients negotiate with insurance companies; she comments on some medical cases she has worked on; three years ago, she started her own business, Health Resources Consultants, Tarrytown; her photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: LAST fall, I was having lunch with a couple of friends, and we were discussing our favorite subject: our harried schedules and how ineptly we were handling them. One said the previous week had been a particular trial. She had scheduled a doctor's visit in the city and forgotten to book a baby sitter. My other friend nodded sympathetically. ''I schedule all my doctor's appointments in the city early in the morning,'' she said, ''so I'm sure I'll be home in time.'' I looked at them incredulously. Neither worked in the city, so why were they going to doctors there?

headline.main: Taking the Bridge or the Tunnel to the Doctor

docs.abstract: Debra Galant (Jersey) column on perception among New Jersey suburbanites that best doctors are in New York City; drawing (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: The official word from President Clinton and Congressional leaders in the aftermath of Friday's impeachment vote was that the time had come to bury the hatchet and work together on important policy issues. But out of camera range, many in the White House and the Capitol said the bad blood was so pervasive, the ideological divisions so vast and the political interests so disparate that they doubted productive bridges could be built between Mr. Clinton and the Republican majority in the Congress.

headline.main: Road to Reconciliation Appears Long and Hard After Acquittal

docs.abstract: Pres Clinton and Republican majority in Congress will have difficult time working with each other on important policy issues, so great is the bad blood aroused over the impeachment ordeal, so vast their ideological divisions and so disparate their political interests; political atmosphere in Congress may have been improved by Republicans' election of Dennis Hastert as Speaker and by newfound camaraderie in Senate; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: THE Roman Catholic Church has always struggled to speak with one voice to both the rich and the poor. Last month, when Pope John Paul II toured Mexico and St. Louis, he sternly warned against a runaway free-market system based on a ''purely economic conception of man.'' But he also exhorted church leaders not to forget the wealthier members of their flock. ''Love for the poor must be preferential, but not exclusive,'' he said. ''The leading sectors of society have been neglected, and many people have thus been estranged from the church.''

headline.main: Taking the Gospel to the Rich

docs.abstract: Profile of Thomas S Monaghan, Domino's Pizza founder, conservative who plans to use personal fortune from sale of company for Catholic causes; he hopes to build Legatus, lay support group for Catholic executives and their spouses, into major force; photos (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: The Justice Department filed a motion to combine all Medicare fraud whistle-blower lawsuits against the Columbia/HCA Healthcare Corporation in a move that prosecutors said would help lead to a settlement of the investigation. ''Transfer will greatly assist the United States and Columbia in ongoing settlement discussions,'' the Justice Department said in its motion.

headline.main: U.S. Seeks to Consolidate Columbia Suits

docs.lead_paragraph: An appellate panel of Superior Court today denied a last-ditch effort by the insolvent HIP Health Plan of New Jersey and its New York parent company to halt the liquidation of the health maintenance organization, which will scatter its 165,000 policyholders to other plans. On a day when state courts were closed -- Lincoln's birthday is still observed as such in New Jersey -- a three-judge panel held the hearing in an emergency 45-minute telephone conference call and denied the appeal by HIP and its New York parent company, H.I.P. Health Plans, upholding a ruling on Thursday by Judge Jack L. Lintner of Middlesex Superior Court.

headline.main: Court Panel Upholds Liquidation of H.M.O.

docs.lead_paragraph: A judge here turned down today a bid by HIP Health Plans of New Jersey and its New York parent company to prevent state regulators from liquidating the health maintenance organization. The ruling keeps in place Monday's decision by state regulators to end their three-month effort to rehabilitate and maintain the 23-clinic system of HIP Health Plans of New Jersey. It also lets stand the state's directive to other health plans in the state to open their enrollments to the 165,000 HIP policy holders, who have until March 31 to obtain new insurance coverage.

headline.main: Judge Rejects Bid to Save Troubled H.M.O.

docs.lead_paragraph: It was the kind of experience Dr. William Lindsey had dreaded. The doctor, a general surgeon, sat on one side of a meeting table protesting a decision by United Healthcare to pay him almost $100 less for each colonoscopy he performs under that managed care plan. The reduction, Dr. Lindsey said, would cost him $30,000 this year.

headline.main: Feeling the Push Of Managed Care; In Syracuse, Doctors and Patients Adjust As H.M.O.'s Make a Late Appearance
